author: Macaulay, Monica Ann
description: Morphology and Cliticization in Chalcatongo Mixtec
howpublished: Tesis de doctorado, Universidad de California, Berkeley, California. 229 pp. Distribuida por University Microfilms International bajo el número AAD88-13982. Resumen publicado en Dissertation abstracts international, vol. 49, 06-A, p. 1445A
jsondata: {"cfn": "north_america\\macaulay_chalcatongo1987_o.pdf", "mpifn": "chalcatongo_macaulay1987_o.pdf", "macro_area": "North America", "glottolog_ref_id": "59591", "digital_formats": "PDF 5.37Mb image-only PDF", "source": "DAI-A 49/06, p. 1445, Dec 1988", "oclc": "697699160", "document_type": "B", "otomanguean_heading": "Mixtec", "class_loc": "PM4016", "src": "hh, mpieva, otomanguean", "lgcode": "Mixtec San Miguel el Grande [mig]", "degree": "PhD", "delivered": "north_america\\macaulay_chalcatongo1987_o.pdf", "abstract": "This dissertation provides a partial sketch of the Chalcatongo dialect of the Otomanguean language Mixtec, with an emphasis on morphology and cliticization. Included are: a phonological sketch, a very brief survey of important syntactic and semantic issues, and a more in-depth look at the types of bound morphemes which are encountered in Mixtec. The dissertation also includes exploration of the characteristics of various types of morphemes, especially of the ill-defined category 'clitic.' Precise delineation of such categories is especially important in description of a language like Mixtec, which makes use of a wide variety of morphological elements: from free words to fossilized remnants of previously productive forms, with a range of categories in between. The identification and characterization of these intermediate categories is one of the central tasks undertaken in this dissertation. A typology of morphological units is developed (drawn largely from the work of Arnold Zwicky) which includes free words, a category of phonologically dependent forms called 'leaners,' bound words, phrasal affixes, and ordinary affixes. Four types of obligatorily bound element are found to be present in Chalcatongo Mixtec: phrasal affixes, inflectional affixes, derivational affixes, and fossilized remnants of old productive systems of classification and aspect marking. A fifth type of bound element is that which results from optional rules of rapid speech. These rules reduce disyllabic free words to monosyllables which are phonologically dependent on a neighboring form. Finally, the historical development of certain areas of the morphology of Chalcatongo Mixtec is explored. While we find that Mixtec is a language whose synchronic state cannot be adequately described without some understanding of the forces which have shaped (and which continue to shape) its grammar, we also find that it is a language for which it is of paramount importance to keep diachronic and synchronic analyses separate. This is important because often the treatment of a subset of data obscures more problematic aspects of a system. For example, the analysis of nasalization extends our understanding of how constraints can combine in a grammar. I motivate the conditional union of two Alignment (McCarthy and Prince 1993a) constraints to characterize attested patterns of root nasality, while ruling out impossible forms. The treatment of glottalization explores the implications of freedom of input in OT. Chapter 3 extends Grounding (Archangeli and Pulleyblank 1994a) to the opportunistically grounded relation between glottalization and stress. Second, building on research in phonetic implementation (Pierrehumbert 1980, Keating 1990b), I show that a phonologically specified (+constricted glottis) must be implemented for only a part of the duration of the specified vowel. The data also argue for a more complex notion of the relationship between phonetic data and phonological information than that of Cohn (1990). jsondata: {"doi": "10.1086/519057", "abstract": "This paper presents a systematic account of the tone system of Pe\u00f1oles Mixtec (PM). While /H/ and /L/ tones are unambiguously needed in underlying representations, we argue that the third tone is not /M/ but must rather be underspecified as /\u00d8/. Perhaps the most interesting of the several arguments presented is that strings of /\u00d8/ tone-bearing units are invisible to a process which deletes the second /L/ of a /L-\u00d8*-L/ sequence. We propose that all /L/ tones are underlying floating and that /L/ rather than /H/ is the marked tone in this three-value system. The surface mid and low-falling pitches in outputs are shown to derive by a small number of realizational rules, which also are responsible for producing successively upstepped H tones.
